newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan central bank says injecting funds.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan central bank says injecting funds.

text.p: Taiwan's central bank, reacting as money rates bubbled ever higher, said it would inject funds into the banking system on Saturday.
A central bank official said the bank would execute open market operations on Saturday through repurchase of negotiable certificates of deposit offered by interested financial institutions.
The institutions have the option of repurchasing the NCDs within six days, the official said.
The central bank said interested financial institutions should contact the bank directly.
Bids would close at 10:00 a.m. (0200 GMT).
Funds would be released according to actual demand, the central bank said.

Taiwan's interbank rate roared into double digits to a record high close on Friday, creating tight liquidity in the banking system as funds continued to stream out of banks into the red-hot stock market.
The overnight interbank rate, capping a 10-session ascent, closed at 10.541 percent against Thursday's 8.597 finish -- roughly double the central bank's 5.0-5.5 percent target zone.
It was the rate's highest close since official recordings began on September 1, 1991. The central bank said it would continue to watch closely the banking system's liquidity flow.
